docTitle.titlePart: Dielectric and structural properties of thin SrHfO 3 layers on TiN

byline.docAuthor:
G. Lupina,
a͒ G. Kozłowski, J. Dabrowski, P. Dudek, G. Lippert, and H.-J. Müssig

front.note: ͑Received 1 October 2008; accepted 22 November 2008; published online 24 December 2008͒
front.div:
We studied several properties of thin amorphous and polycrystalline SrHfO 3 layers on TiN in the
context of memory capacitor applications. Amorphous SrHfO 3 has the dielectric constant ␬ = 21 and
is transformed upon rapid thermal annealing into polycrystalline SrHfO 3 with ␬ = 35. We discuss the
influence of the annealing treatment on leakage currents, and briefly discuss, on the basis of ab initio
calculations, the possible role of vacancylike defects and Ti contamination.

Innovations in architecture and materials are expected to
drive future scaling and performance increase of memory
devices.
1,2 To satisfy requirements of high capacitance den-
sity and low leakage current in advanced high-␬ capacitors,
various dielectric materials are investigated. Despite the con-
troversial issue of grain boundaries which may act as leakage
sites,
3,4 the interest of researchers is now focused rather on
polycrystalline than amorphous insulators.
5 This trend is
mainly due to the fact that polycrystalline materials generally
offer higher dielectric constants ␬ than their amorphous
analog. For this reason, crystalline phases of well known
high-␬ dielectrics such as HfO 2 and ZrO 2 as well as struc-
tural phase transformations in these systems attracted much
attention.
6–10 Another interesting group of materials are poly-
crystalline complex metal oxides, which crystallize in the
perovskite structure.
